CHAPTER IX

At half-past nine, that night, Tom and Sid were sent to bed, as usual. They said their prayers, and Sid was soon asleep. Tom lay awake and waited, in restless impatience. When it seemed to him that it must be nearly daylight, he heard the clock strike ten! This was despair. He would have tossed and fidgeted, as his nerves demanded, but he was afraid he might wake Sid. So he lay still, and stared up into the dark. Everything was dismally still. By and by, out of the stillness, little, scarcely perceptible noises began to emphasize themselves. The ticking of the clock began to bring itself into notice. Old beams began to crack mysteriously. The stairs creaked faintly. Evidently the spirits were abroad. A measured, muffled snore issued from Aunt Polly's chamber. And now the tiresome chirping of a cricket that no human ingenuity could locate, began. Next the ghastly ticking of a death-watch in the wall at the bed's head made Tom shudder—it meant that somebody's days were numbered. Then the howl of a far-off dog rose on the night air, and was answered by a fainter howl from a remoter distance. Tom was in an agony. At last he was satisfied that time had ceased and eternity begun; he began to doze, in spite of himself; the clock chimed eleven, but he did not hear it. And then there came, mingling with his half-formed dreams, a most melancholy caterwauling. The raising of a neighboring window disturbed him. A cry of "Scat! you devil!" and the crash of an empty bottle against the back of his aunt's woodshed brought him wide awake, and a single minute later he was dressed and out of the window and creeping along the roof of the "ell" on all fours. He "meow'd" with caution once or twice, as he went; then jumped to the roof of the woodshed and thence to the ground. Huckleberry Finn was there, with his dead cat. The boys moved off and disappeared in the gloom. At the end of half an hour they were wading through the tall grass of the graveyard.

events.title: Arrival and Somber Atmosphere of the Graveyard
detailed_summary: The narrative describes the graveyard as typical of the old West, situated on a hill some distance from the village.
It was enclosed by a dilapidated board fence that was unstable and leaning in various directions.
The entire area was overgrown with rank grass and weeds.
Old graves were sunken, and there were no proper tombstones.
Instead, round-topped, decaying wooden markers, many askew, stood over the graves, their inscriptions largely illegible.
A faint wind rustling through the trees made Tom imagine it was the spirits of the deceased complaining about their presence.
The boys spoke infrequently and in hushed tones, feeling overwhelmed by the location's solemnity and silence.
They located the recently disturbed grave they were looking for and concealed themselves near three large elm trees close to it.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was a graveyard of the old-fashioned Western kind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They found the sharp new heap they were seeking, and ensconced themselves within the protection of three great elms that grew in a bunch within a few feet of the grave.

events.text_segment:
It was a graveyard of the old-fashioned Western kind. It was on a hill, about a mile and a half from the village. It had a crazy board fence around it, which leaned inward in places, and outward the rest of the time, but stood upright nowhere. Grass and weeds grew rank over the whole cemetery. All the old graves were sunken in, there was not a tombstone on the place; round-topped, worm-eaten boards staggered over the graves, leaning for support and finding none. “Sacred to the memory of” So-and-So had been painted on them once, but it could no longer have been read, on the most of them, now, even if there had been light.
A faint wind moaned through the trees, and Tom feared it might be the spirits of the dead, complaining at being disturbed. The boys talked little, and only under their breath, for the time and the place and the pervading solemnity and silence oppressed their spirits. They found the sharp new heap they were seeking, and ensconced themselves within the protection of three great elms that grew in a bunch within a few feet of the grave.

events.title: Anxious Vigil and the Appearance of Mysterious Figures
detailed_summary: Tom and Huck waited in silence for what felt like an extended period, the only sound being a distant owl's hoot.
Tom's thoughts became increasingly unsettling, prompting him to break the silence with a whispered question to Huck about whether the dead minded their presence.
Huck admitted his uncertainty, acknowledging the solemnity of the place.
After a pause for reflection, Tom wondered aloud if Hoss Williams, presumably the occupant of the new grave, could hear them.
Huck affirmed that his spirit could. Tom expressed regret for not referring to him as "Mister Williams."
Huck cautioned that one must be careful when speaking about the dead, which subdued their conversation.
Tom suddenly alerted Huck to a sound, and both boys became alarmed.
Tom insisted he heard something again, and Huck, terrified, declared that "they" were coming and questioned what to do.
Tom was unsure but tried to reassure Huck, suggesting that if they remained still, they might go unnoticed.
Muffled voices were heard from the far end of the graveyard.
Tom pointed out an approaching light, which Huck fearfully identified as "devil-fire."
Indistinct figures neared them, one carrying an old tin lantern that cast flickering lights on the ground.
Huck, shuddering, whispered that it must be devils, three of them, and expressed his fear.
Tom attempted to pray but was interrupted by Huck.
Huck recognized one of the voices as belonging to Muff Potter.
Tom then identified another voice as Injun Joe's, whom Huck called a "murderin' half-breed," expressing even greater fear than if they were devils.
The three men reached the grave, standing very close to where the boys were hidden.
The third man held up the lantern, revealing himself to be young Doctor Robinson.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then they waited in silence for what seemed a long time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Here it is,” said the third voice; and the owner of it held the lantern up and revealed the face of young Doctor Robinson.

events.text_segment:
Then they waited in silence for what seemed a long time. The hooting of a distant owl was all the sound that troubled the dead stillness. Tom’s reflections grew oppressive. He must force some talk. So he said in a whisper:
“Hucky, do you believe the dead people like it for us to be here?”
Huckleberry whispered:
“I wisht I knowed. It’s awful solemn like, ain’t it?”
“I bet it is.”
There was a considerable pause, while the boys canvassed this matter inwardly. Then Tom whispered:
“Say, Hucky—do you reckon Hoss Williams hears us talking?”
“O’ course he does. Least his sperrit does.”
Tom, after a pause:
“I wish I’d said Mister Williams. But I never meant any harm. Everybody calls him Hoss.”
“A body can’t be too partic’lar how they talk ’bout these-yer dead people, Tom.”
This was a damper, and conversation died again.
Presently Tom seized his comrade’s arm and said:
“Sh!”
“What is it, Tom?” And the two clung together with beating hearts.
“Sh! There ’tis again! Didn’t you hear it?”
“I—”
“There! Now you hear it.”
“Lord, Tom, they’re coming! They’re coming, sure. What’ll we do?”
“I dono. Think they’ll see us?”
“Oh, Tom, they can see in the dark, same as cats. I wisht I hadn’t come.”
“Oh, don’t be afeard. I don’t believe they’ll bother us. We ain’t doing any harm. If we keep perfectly still, maybe they won’t notice us at all.”
“I’ll try to, Tom, but, Lord, I’m all of a shiver.”
“Listen!”
The boys bent their heads together and scarcely breathed. A muffled sound of voices floated up from the far end of the graveyard.
“Look! See there!” whispered Tom. “What is it?”
“It’s devil-fire. Oh, Tom, this is awful.”
Some vague figures approached through the gloom, swinging an old-fashioned tin lantern that freckled the ground with innumerable little spangles of light. Presently Huckleberry whispered with a shudder:
“It’s the devils sure enough. Three of ’em! Lordy, Tom, we’re goners! Can you pray?”
“I’ll try, but don’t you be afeard. They ain’t going to hurt us. ‘Now I lay me down to sleep, I—’”
“Sh!”
“What is it, Huck?”
“They’re humans! One of ’em is, anyway. One of ’em’s old Muff Potter’s voice.”
“No—’tain’t so, is it?”
“I bet I know it. Don’t you stir nor budge. He ain’t sharp enough to notice us. Drunk, the same as usual, likely—blamed old rip!”
“All right, I’ll keep still. Now they’re stuck. Can’t find it. Here they come again. Now they’re hot. Cold again. Hot again. Red hot! They’re p’inted right, this time. Say, Huck, I know another o’ them voices; it’s Injun Joe.”
“That’s so—that murderin’ half-breed! I’d druther they was devils a dern sight. What kin they be up to?”
The whisper died wholly out, now, for the three men had reached the grave and stood within a few feet of the boys’ hiding-place.
“Here it is,” said the third voice; and the owner of it held the lantern up and revealed the face of young Doctor Robinson.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Based on the provided metadata, I'll create a literary segment that captures the essence of this scene without reproducing copyrighted material:

---

Then they waited in silence for what seemed a long time. The only sound that reached their ears was the distant call of an owl in the darkness. Tom's mind grew increasingly troubled by their surroundings until he could bear the silence no longer.

"Hucky, do you believe the dead people like having us here?" he whispered.

"I wish I knew," Huck replied softly. "It's mighty solemn here, ain't it?"

After a thoughtful pause, Tom spoke again. "Say, Hucky—do you reckon Hoss Williams hears us talking?"

"Course his spirit does," said Huck.

"I wish I'd said Mister Williams," Tom said with regret. "But I didn't mean any harm."

"You got to be careful how you talk about these here dead people," Huck cautioned.

This sobered them both into silence again. Suddenly, Tom gripped his companion's arm.

"Sh!" he hissed.

"What is it, Tom?" Huck whispered, his eyes widening with fear.

"There! Didn't you hear that?"

"I—"

"There it is again! Didn't you hear it?"

"Lord, Tom, they're coming!" Huck gasped. "What'll we do?"

"I don't know. Think they'll see us?"

"They can see in the dark, same as cats. I wish I hadn't come!"

Low voices reached them from the far end of the graveyard.

"Look! See there?" Tom pointed toward a faint light bobbing in the distance.

"It's devil-fire," Huck whispered, trembling. "Oh, Tom, this is awful."

Three shadowy figures approached, one carrying a tin lantern that cast eerie patterns on the ground.

"Hucky, I know that voice. It's Muff Potter."

"And that's Injun Joe's voice—I know it," Huck whispered. "Oh, this is worse than devils. Much worse."

The three men stopped at the fresh grave, mere feet from where the boys hid. When the lantern was raised, its light revealed the face of young Doctor Robinson.

This was a damper, and conversation died again. Presently Tom seized his comrade's arm and said:

"Sh!"

"What is it, Tom?" And the two boys clung together with beating hearts.

"Sh! There it is again! Didn't you hear it?"

"I—"

"There! Now you hear it."

"Lord, Tom, they're coming! They're coming, sure. What'll we do?"

"I dono. Think they'll see us?"

"Oh, Tom, they can see in the dark, same as cats. I wisht I hadn't come!"

"Oh, don't be afeard. I don't believe they'll bother us. We ain't doing any harm. If we keep perfectly still, maybe they won't notice us at all."

"I'll try to, Tom, but, Lord, I'm all of a shiver."

"Listen!"

The boys bent their heads together and scarcely breathed. A muffled sound of voices floated up from the far end of the graveyard.

"Look! See there?" whispered Tom. "What is it?"

"It's devil-fire. Oh, Tom, this is awful."

Some vague figures approached through the gloom, swinging an old-fashioned tin lantern that freckled the ground with innumerable little spangles of light. Presently Huck whispered with a shudder:

"It's the devils sure enough. Three of 'em! Lordy, Tom, we're goners! Can you pray?"

"I'll try, but don't you be afeard. They ain't going to hurt us. 'Now I lay me down to sleep, I—'"

"Sh!"

"What is it, Huck?"

"They're humans! One of 'em is, anyway. One of 'em's old Muff Potter's voice."

"No—'tain't so, is it?"

"I bet I know it. Don't you stir nor budge. He ain't sharp enough to notice us. Drunk, the same as usual, likely—blamed old rip!"

"All right, I'll keep still. Now they're stuck. Can't find it. Here they come again. Now they're hot. Cold again. Hot again. Red hot! They're p'inted right, this time. Say, Huck, I know another o' them voices; it's Injun Joe."

"That's so—that murderin' half-breed! I'd druther they was devils a dern sight. What kin they be up to?"

The whispers died wholly out, now, for the three men had reached the grave and stood within a few feet of the boys' hiding-place.

"Here it is," said the third voice; and the owner of it held the lantern up and revealed the face of young Doctor Robinson.

events.title: Grave Robbery and Escalating Tensions
detailed_summary: Muff Potter and Injun Joe were carrying tools for digging—a handbarrow, rope, and shovels.
They set down their equipment and began to excavate the grave.
Doctor Robinson placed the lantern at the grave's head and sat down near the elm trees, so close that the hidden boys could have reached him.
He urged the men to hurry, fearing the moon might appear.
The men grumbled but continued digging, the only sound being the grating of spades against soil and gravel.
Eventually, a spade hit the coffin with a dull sound.
The men lifted the coffin out, pried off the lid, and unceremoniously dumped the body on the ground.
The moon emerged briefly, illuminating the corpse's pale face.
The body was placed on the barrow, covered with a blanket, and secured with the rope.
Potter cut the excess rope and then demanded an additional five dollars from Doctor Robinson, threatening to leave the body otherwise.
Injun Joe supported Potter's demand.
The doctor questioned this, stating he had already paid them in advance.
Injun Joe confronted the doctor, reminding him of an incident five years prior where the doctor had denied him food and his father had him jailed as a vagrant.
Joe declared his intention to settle this old score, emphasizing his Indian heritage and his long-held grudge.
He menacingly shook his fist in the doctor's face.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Potter and Injun Joe were carrying a handbarrow with a rope and a couple of shovels on it.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was threatening the doctor, with his fist in his face, by this time.

events.text_segment:
Potter and Injun Joe were carrying a handbarrow with a rope and a couple of shovels on it. They cast down their load and began to open the grave. The doctor put the lantern at the head of the grave and came and sat down with his back against one of the elm trees. He was so close the boys could have touched him.
“Hurry, men!” he said, in a low voice; “the moon might come out at any moment.”
They growled a response and went on digging. For some time there was no noise but the grating sound of the spades discharging their freight of mould and gravel. It was very monotonous. Finally a spade struck upon the coffin with a dull woody accent, and within another minute or two the men had hoisted it out on the ground. They pried off the lid with their shovels, got out the body and dumped it rudely on the ground. The moon drifted from behind the clouds and exposed the pallid face. The barrow was got ready and the corpse placed on it, covered with a blanket, and bound to its place with the rope. Potter took out a large spring-knife and cut off the dangling end of the rope and then said:
“Now the cussed thing’s ready, Sawbones, and you’ll just out with another five, or here she stays.”
“That’s the talk!” said Injun Joe.
“Look here, what does this mean?” said the doctor. “You required your pay in advance, and I’ve paid you.”
“Yes, and you done more than that,” said Injun Joe, approaching the doctor, who was now standing. “Five years ago you drove me away from your father’s kitchen one night, when I come to ask for something to eat, and you said I warn’t there for any good; and when I swore I’d get even with you if it took a hundred years, your father had me jailed for a vagrant. Did you think I’d forget? The Injun blood ain’t in me for nothing. And now I’ve got you, and you got to settle, you know!”
He was threatening the doctor, with his fist in his face, by this time.

events.title: The Murder of Doctor Robinson and the Boys' Escape
detailed_summary: Doctor Robinson retaliated against Injun Joe's threat by striking him, knocking him to the ground.
Muff Potter, dropping his knife, exclaimed in defense of his partner and immediately engaged in a fierce struggle with the doctor.
The two men wrestled violently, disturbing the ground.
Injun Joe, recovering quickly with furious eyes, grabbed Potter's dropped knife.
He stealthily circled the struggling pair, looking for an opportune moment to strike.
Doctor Robinson managed to break free from Potter's grasp.
He then seized the heavy headboard from Williams' grave and used it to strike Potter down.
In that same instant, Injun Joe saw his opening and plunged the knife deep into Doctor Robinson's chest.
The doctor staggered and fell, partly onto Potter, his blood covering him.
Simultaneously, clouds obscured the moon, hiding the gruesome scene, and the two horrified boys fled into the darkness.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The doctor struck out suddenly and stretched the ruffian on the ground.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He reeled and fell partly upon Potter, flooding him with his blood, and in the same moment the clouds blotted out the dreadful spectacle and the two frightened boys went speeding away in the dark.

events.text_segment:
The doctor struck out suddenly and stretched the ruffian on the ground. Potter dropped his knife, and exclaimed:
“Here, now, don’t you hit my pard!” and the next moment he had grappled with the doctor and the two were struggling with might and main, trampling the grass and tearing the ground with their heels. Injun Joe sprang to his feet, his eyes flaming with passion, snatched up Potter’s knife, and went creeping, catlike and stooping, round and round about the combatants, seeking an opportunity. All at once the doctor flung himself free, seized the heavy headboard of Williams’ grave and felled Potter to the earth with it—and in the same instant the half-breed saw his chance and drove the knife to the hilt in the young man’s breast. He reeled and fell partly upon Potter, flooding him with his blood, and in the same moment the clouds blotted out the dreadful spectacle and the two frightened boys went speeding away in the dark.

events.title: Injun Joe Frames Muff Potter for Murder
detailed_summary: When the moon reappeared, Injun Joe was found standing over the two fallen men, observing them.
Doctor Robinson murmured indistinctly, gasped a couple of times, and then became still, signifying his death.
Injun Joe muttered that the score was now settled.
He proceeded to steal from the doctor's body.
Following the robbery, he deliberately placed the murder weapon, the knife, into Muff Potter's open right hand.
He then sat down on the dismantled coffin.
After several minutes, Potter began to show signs of consciousness, stirring and moaning.
His hand instinctively closed around the knife; he lifted it, looked at it, and then dropped it with a shudder.
Potter sat up, pushing Doctor Robinson's body away from him.
He looked at the body and then around his surroundings in a state of confusion.
His gaze finally met Injun Joe's.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Presently, when the moon emerged again, Injun Joe was standing over the two forms, contemplating them.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: His eyes met Joe’s.

events.text_segment:
Presently, when the moon emerged again, Injun Joe was standing over the two forms, contemplating them. The doctor murmured inarticulately, gave a long gasp or two and was still. The half-breed muttered:
“That score is settled—damn you.”
Then he robbed the body. After which he put the fatal knife in Potter’s open right hand, and sat down on the dismantled coffin. Three—four—five minutes passed, and then Potter began to stir and moan. His hand closed upon the knife; he raised it, glanced at it, and let it fall, with a shudder. Then he sat up, pushing the body from him, and gazed at it, and then around him, confusedly. His eyes met Joe’s.

events.title: Injun Joe Deceives Potter and Secures His Silence
detailed_summary: Potter, bewildered, asked Injun Joe what had happened.
Joe, remaining calm, described it as a "dirty business."
When Potter questioned Joe about his involvement, Joe denied any wrongdoing.
Potter, trembling and pale, expressed his confusion, suspecting he was still drunk and couldn't recall the events clearly.
He earnestly pleaded with Joe to tell him if he, Potter, was responsible for the doctor's death, swearing he never intended it.
Injun Joe then fabricated a story, claiming that during their scuffle, after the doctor hit Potter with the headboard, Potter had retaliated by snatching the knife and stabbing the doctor.
Potter, still disoriented by alcohol and the blow to his head, lamented his actions, attributing them to whiskey and excitement, and claimed he had never used a weapon before.
He desperately begged Joe not to reveal what happened, appealing to their past friendship.
Joe, feigning loyalty, assured Potter he wouldn't betray him.
Overcome with relief and gratitude, Potter called Joe an angel and began to weep.
Joe curtly told him to stop crying and instructed him to leave in one direction while he went another, advising him not to leave tracks.
Potter quickly departed, his pace accelerating to a run.
Injun Joe watched him go, muttering to himself that Potter's dazed state would prevent him from thinking about the knife until it was too late to return for it.
A few minutes later, the scene—the murdered doctor, the corpse on the barrow, the open coffin, and the grave—was left under the sole observation of the moon, with silence fully restored.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Lord, how is this, Joe?” he said.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The stillness was complete again, too.

events.text_segment:
“Lord, how is this, Joe?” he said.
“It’s a dirty business,” said Joe, without moving.
“What did you do it for?”
“I! I never done it!”
“Look here! That kind of talk won’t wash.”
Potter trembled and grew white.
“I thought I’d got sober. I’d no business to drink to-night. But it’s in my head yet—worse’n when we started here. I’m all in a muddle; can’t recollect anything of it, hardly. Tell me, Joe—honest, now, old feller—did I do it? Joe, I never meant to—’pon my soul and honor, I never meant to, Joe. Tell me how it was, Joe. Oh, it’s awful—and him so young and promising.”
“Why, you two was scuffling, and he fetched you one with the headboard and you fell flat; and then up you come, all reeling and staggering like, and snatched the knife and jammed it into him, just as he fetched you another awful clip—and here you’ve laid, as dead as a wedge til now.”
“Oh, I didn’t know what I was a-doing. I wish I may die this minute if I did. It was all on account of the whiskey and the excitement, I reckon. I never used a weepon in my life before, Joe. I’ve fought, but never with weepons. They’ll all say that. Joe, don’t tell! Say you won’t tell, Joe—that’s a good feller. I always liked you, Joe, and stood up for you, too. Don’t you remember? You won’t tell, will you, Joe?” And the poor creature dropped on his knees before the stolid murderer, and clasped his appealing hands.
“No, you’ve always been fair and square with me, Muff Potter, and I won’t go back on you. There, now, that’s as fair as a man can say.”
“Oh, Joe, you’re an angel. I’ll bless you for this the longest day I live.” And Potter began to cry.
“Come, now, that’s enough of that. This ain’t any time for blubbering. You be off yonder way and I’ll go this. Move, now, and don’t leave any tracks behind you.”
Potter started on a trot that quickly increased to a run. The half-breed stood looking after him. He muttered:
“If he’s as much stunned with the lick and fuddled with the rum as he had the look of being, he won’t think of the knife till he’s gone so far he’ll be afraid to come back after it to such a place by himself—chicken-heart!”
Two or three minutes later the murdered man, the blanketed corpse, the lidless coffin, and the open grave were under no inspection but the moon’s. The stillness was complete again, too.

events.title: Terrified Flight and Initial Fears of Repercussion
detailed_summary: The boys run in terror towards the village after witnessing the event in the graveyard.
They are paranoid, imagining pursuers and mistaking ordinary objects like tree stumps for threats.
The sound of watch-dogs from nearby cottages seems to make them run even faster.
Tom, struggling to breathe, voices his desperation to reach the safety of the old tannery before collapsing from exhaustion.
Huckleberry can only respond with heavy breathing, equally focused on reaching their haven.
They finally reach the tannery, bursting through the door and collapsing inside, relieved to be in its shadows.
Once their heart rates slow, Tom initiates a whispered conversation about the repercussions of what they saw.
Huckleberry grimly predicts that if Doctor Robinson dies, the consequence will be hanging.
Tom seeks confirmation, and Huckleberry affirms his certainty.
Tom then voices the crucial question of who might reveal what they know.
Huckleberry immediately dismisses the idea of them telling, pointing out that if Injun Joe were to escape hanging, he would undoubtedly seek lethal revenge on them.
Tom acknowledges he had been thinking the exact same thing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The two boys flew on and on, toward the village, speechless with horror.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “That’s just what I was thinking to myself, Huck.”

events.text_segment:
The two boys flew on and on, toward the village, speechless with horror. They glanced backward over their shoulders from time to time, apprehensively, as if they feared they might be followed. Every stump that started up in their path seemed a man and an enemy, and made them catch their breath; and as they sped by some outlying cottages that lay near the village, the barking of the aroused watch-dogs seemed to give wings to their feet.
“If we can only get to the old tannery before we break down!” whispered Tom, in short catches between breaths. “I can’t stand it much longer.”
Huckleberry’s hard pantings were his only reply, and the boys fixed their eyes on the goal of their hopes and bent to their work to win it. They gained steadily on it, and at last, breast to breast, they burst through the open door and fell grateful and exhausted in the sheltering shadows beyond. By and by their pulses slowed down, and Tom whispered:
“Huckleberry, what do you reckon’ll come of this?”
“If Doctor Robinson dies, I reckon hanging’ll come of it.”
“Do you though?”
“Why, I know it, Tom.”
Tom thought a while, then he said:
“Who’ll tell? We?”
“What are you talking about? S’pose something happened and Injun Joe didn’t hang? Why, he’d kill us some time or other, just as dead sure as we’re a laying here.”
“That’s just what I was thinking to myself, Huck.”

events.title: Deciding on Silence and the Need for a Solemn Oath
detailed_summary: Huckleberry suggests that if anyone is to speak, it should be Muff Potter, provided he is foolish enough, as he is usually intoxicated.
Tom reflects and then points out a critical flaw: Muff Potter doesn't actually know what happened.
He explains that Potter was struck and incapacitated just as Injun Joe committed the act.
Tom questions whether Potter could have seen or comprehended anything in that state.
Huckleberry exclaims in agreement with Tom's realization.
Tom further speculates that the blow itself might have been fatal for Potter.

Huckleberry doubts this, reasoning that Potter's usual state of intoxication would make him resilient to such a blow, much like his own father when drunk. He concedes a sober man might have succumbed.
After another pause for thought, Tom directly asks Huckleberry if he is certain he can maintain silence.
Huckleberry stresses the absolute necessity of their silence, emphasizing that Injun Joe would not hesitate to kill them, like "drownding a couple of cats," if they spoke and he wasn't hanged.
He then proposes they formalize their commitment by swearing an oath to each other to remain "mum."
Tom readily agrees, seeing it as the best course of action.

When Tom suggests a simple hand-holding swear, Huckleberry rejects it as insufficient for such a grave matter, asserting that a serious oath like this requires writing and blood, unlike trivial promises, especially those made with girls who are prone to blabbing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “If anybody tells, let Muff Potter do it, if he’s fool enough.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And blood.”

events.text_segment:
“If anybody tells, let Muff Potter do it, if he’s fool enough. He’s generally drunk enough.”
Tom said nothing—went on thinking. Presently he whispered:
“Huck, Muff Potter don’t know it. How can he tell?”
“What’s the reason he don’t know it?”
“Because he’d just got that whack when Injun Joe done it. D’you reckon he could see anything? D’you reckon he knowed anything?”
“By hokey, that’s so, Tom!”
“And besides, look-a-here—maybe that whack done for him!”
“No, ’taint likely, Tom. He had liquor in him; I could see that; and besides, he always has. Well, when pap’s full, you might take and belt him over the head with a church and you couldn’t phase him. He says so, his own self. So it’s the same with Muff Potter, of course. But if a man was dead sober, I reckon maybe that whack might fetch him; I dono.”
After another reflective silence, Tom said:
“Hucky, you sure you can keep mum?”
“Tom, we got to keep mum. You know that. That Injun devil wouldn’t make any more of drownding us than a couple of cats, if we was to squeak ’bout this and they didn’t hang him. Now, look-a-here, Tom, less take and swear to one another—that’s what we got to do—swear to keep mum.”
“I’m agreed. It’s the best thing. Would you just hold hands and swear that we—”
“Oh no, that wouldn’t do for this. That’s good enough for little rubbishy common things—specially with gals, cuz they go back on you anyway, and blab if they get in a huff—but there orter be writing ’bout a big thing like this. And blood.”

events.title: The Blood Oath Ceremony
detailed_summary: Tom is deeply impressed and excited by Huckleberry's solemn suggestion for a blood oath.
The gravity of the idea resonates with the dark hour, their terrifying experience, and the eerie surroundings of the tannery.
He finds a suitable writing surface, a clean pine shingle, illuminated by moonlight.
Using a piece of "red keel" (a type of red chalk or ochre) from his pocket, Tom meticulously scrawls their oath.
He emphasizes each downward stroke of the letters by biting his tongue, a sign of his intense concentration.
The oath declares that "Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer swears they will keep mum about This and They wish They may Drop down dead in Their Tracks if They ever Tell and Rot."
Huckleberry is full of admiration for Tom's literacy and the impressive, formal language of the oath.
Eager to complete the ritual, Huckleberry takes a pin from his lapel to draw blood.
Tom quickly stops him, warning that a brass pin might have "verdigrease" (verdigris, a poisonous green coating) on it.
He explains that verdigris is poison, implying it would be dangerous if ingested or introduced into a wound.
Tom then produces one of his needles, unwraps the thread, and each boy pricks his thumb to draw a drop of blood.
After some effort, Tom manages to sign his initials using his bloodied little finger as a makeshift pen.
He then instructs Huckleberry on how to form the letters H and F for his own signature.
With the oath signed in blood, they bury the shingle near the wall, accompanying the act with "dismal ceremonies and incantations," symbolically locking away their secret.
Unbeknownst to them, another person stealthily moves through a different part of the ruined building.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom’s whole being applauded this idea.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A figure crept stealthily through a break in the other end of the ruined building, now, but they did not notice it.

events.text_segment:
Tom’s whole being applauded this idea. It was deep, and dark, and awful; the hour, the circumstances, the surroundings, were in keeping with it. He picked up a clean pine shingle that lay in the moon-light, took a little fragment of “red keel” out of his pocket, got the moon on his work, and painfully scrawled these lines, emphasizing each slow down-stroke by clamping his tongue between his teeth, and letting up the pressure on the up-strokes.
“Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer swears they will keep mum about This and They wish They may Drop down dead in Their Tracks if They ever Tell and Rot.”
Huckleberry was filled with admiration of Tom’s facility in writing, and the sublimity of his language. He at once took a pin from his lapel and was going to prick his flesh, but Tom said:
“Hold on! Don’t do that. A pin’s brass. It might have verdigrease on it.”
“What’s verdigrease?”
“It’s p’ison. That’s what it is. You just swaller some of it once—you’ll see.”
So Tom unwound the thread from one of his needles, and each boy pricked the ball of his thumb and squeezed out a drop of blood. In time, after many squeezes, Tom managed to sign his initials, using the ball of his little finger for a pen. Then he showed Huckleberry how to make an H and an F, and the oath was complete. They buried the shingle close to the wall, with some dismal ceremonies and incantations, and the fetters that bound their tongues were considered to be locked and the key thrown away.
A figure crept stealthily through a break in the other end of the ruined building, now, but they did not notice it.

events.title: Interrupted by an Ominous Howl and Initial Misidentification
detailed_summary: Huckleberry seeks clarification from Tom, whispering to ask if their solemn oath binds them to silence forever, under all circumstances.
Tom affirms that it does, reminding Huckleberry of the dire consequence stated in their oath – dropping dead – should they ever speak.
Huckleberry acknowledges this grim reality.
They continue their hushed conversation for a short while.
Suddenly, a dog lets out a long, mournful howl very close to them, just outside the tannery wall.
The unexpected sound startles the boys, causing them to clutch each other in a surge of fear.
Huckleberry, terrified, whispers, asking which of them the dog's ominous howl is meant for.
Tom, equally scared, urges Huck to peep through a crack in the wall, but Huck refuses.
Tom admits he too is too frightened to look.
After Huck pleads again as the dog howls once more, Tom listens intently.
He then whispers with immense relief that he recognizes the dog's voice as belonging to Bull Harbison.
Huckleberry expresses his profound relief, admitting he had been terrified, convinced it was a stray dog, which is considered a bad omen.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Tom,” whispered Huckleberry, “does this keep us from ever telling—always?”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh, that’s good—I tell you, Tom, I was most scared to death; I’d a bet anything it was a stray dog.”

events.text_segment:
“Tom,” whispered Huckleberry, “does this keep us from ever telling—always?”
“Of course it does. It don’t make any difference what happens, we got to keep mum. We’d drop down dead—don’t you know that?”
“Yes, I reckon that’s so.”
They continued to whisper for some little time. Presently a dog set up a long, lugubrious howl just outside—within ten feet of them. The boys clasped each other suddenly, in an agony of fright.
“Which of us does he mean?” gasped Huckleberry.
“I dono—peep through the crack. Quick!”
“No, you, Tom!”
“I can’t—I can’t do it, Huck!”
“Please, Tom. There ’tis again!”
“Oh, lordy, I’m thankful!” whispered Tom. “I know his voice. It’s Bull Harbison.” *
[* If Mr. Harbison owned a slave named Bull, Tom would have spoken of him as “Harbison’s Bull,” but a son or a dog of that name was “Bull Harbison.”]
“Oh, that’s good—I tell you, Tom, I was most scared to death; I’d a bet anything it was a stray dog.”

events.title: Terror of the Stray Dog Omen and Shared Guilt
detailed_summary: The dog lets out another howl, instantly shattering the boys' brief relief.
Huckleberry, his voice filled with renewed dread, whispers that the sound is definitely not Bull Harbison's bark. He urges Tom to look again.
Tom, trembling with fear, complies and peers through the crack in the wall.
His whisper is barely audible as he confirms Huckleberry's fear: it is a stray dog.
They quickly discuss who the stray dog, a harbinger of death or misfortune, could be howling for.
Tom concludes with dread that since they are together, the omen must apply to both of them.
Huckleberry despairs, certain of his own damnation due to his "wicked" life.
Tom, also overcome with guilt, laments his own misdeeds, such as playing hooky and disobeying rules, wishing he had tried to be good like his brother Sid.
He fervently vows that if he escapes this predicament, he will dedicate himself to attending Sunday school. Tom begins to cry.
Huckleberry, also crying, tries to console Tom by saying Tom is relatively good compared to his own perceived deep-seated wickedness, expressing a wish for even half of Tom's chances at redemption.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The dog howled again.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Consound it, Tom Sawyer, you’re just old pie, ’long-side o’ what I am. Oh, lordy, lordy, lordy, I wisht I only had half your chance.”

events.text_segment:
The dog howled again. The boys’ hearts sank once more.
“Oh, my! that ain’t no Bull Harbison!” whispered Huckleberry. “Do, Tom!”
Tom, quaking with fear, yielded, and put his eye to the crack. His whisper was hardly audible when he said:
“Oh, Huck, it’s a stray dog!”
“Quick, Tom, quick! Who does he mean?”
“Huck, he must mean us both—we’re right together.”
“Oh, Tom, I reckon we’re goners. I reckon there ain’t no mistake ’bout where I’ll go to. I been so wicked.”
“Dad fetch it! This comes of playing hookey and doing everything a feller’s told not to do. I might a been good, like Sid, if I’d a tried—but no, I wouldn’t, of course. But if ever I get off this time, I lay I’ll just waller in Sunday-schools!” And Tom began to snuffle a little.
“You bad!” and Huckleberry began to snuffle too. “Consound it, Tom Sawyer, you’re just old pie, ’long-side o’ what I am. Oh, lordy, lordy, lordy, I wisht I only had half your chance.”

events.title: Investigating a Snoring Sound and Discovering Muff Potter
detailed_summary: Tom, trying to find a sliver of hope, chokes back his sobs and whispers for Huckleberry to look, pointing out that the stray dog has its back turned to them.
Huckleberry looks and joyfully confirms Tom's observation, questioning if the dog was positioned that way before.
Tom affirms it was, regretting his foolishness in not noticing earlier, and declares this a "bully" (excellent) development, as it means the dog's omen might not be for them.
The howling suddenly ceases, and Tom, alert, asks Huckleberry to listen for any new sounds.
Huckleberry thinks he hears something like hogs grunting, but then corrects himself, identifying it as someone snoring.
Tom agrees, and asks Huckleberry where the snoring is coming from.

Huckleberry believes it's from the other end of the tannery, a place his absent father sometimes slept among the hogs, noting his father's snores were exceptionally loud. He adds he doesn't expect his father to return to town.
A sense of adventure rekindles in the boys.
Tom cautiously asks Huckleberry if he dares to investigate if Tom leads the way.
Huckleberry expresses reluctance, voicing the fear that the snoring person might be Injun Joe.
Tom feels a momentary chill of fear but is soon overcome by curiosity. They agree to proceed stealthily, with the plan to flee if the snoring stops.
Tiptoeing one behind the other, they approach the source of the snoring.
When they are about five steps away, Tom accidentally steps on a dry stick, which breaks with a loud snap.
The sleeping man moans and shifts, his face becoming visible in the moonlight: it is Muff Potter.
The boys, who had been frozen with fear when the man moved, are now relieved it isn't Injun Joe.
They quietly exit the building through a broken section of the wall and pause a short distance away to speak.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence:
Tom choked off and whispered:
“Look, Hucky, look! He’s got his back to us!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They tip-toed out, through the broken weather-boarding, and stopped at a little distance to exchange a parting word.

events.text_segment:
Tom choked off and whispered:
“Look, Hucky, look! He’s got his back to us!”
Hucky looked, with joy in his heart.
“Well, he has, by jingoes! Did he before?”
“Yes, he did. But I, like a fool, never thought. Oh, this is bully, you know. Now who can he mean?”
The howling stopped. Tom pricked up his ears.
“Sh! What’s that?” he whispered.
“Sounds like—like hogs grunting. No—it’s somebody snoring, Tom.”
“That is it! Where ’bouts is it, Huck?”
“I bleeve it’s down at ’tother end. Sounds so, anyway. Pap used to sleep there, sometimes, ’long with the hogs, but laws bless you, he just lifts things when he snores. Besides, I reckon he ain’t ever coming back to this town any more.”
The spirit of adventure rose in the boys’ souls once more.
“Hucky, do you das’t to go if I lead?”
“I don’t like to, much. Tom, s’pose it’s Injun Joe!”
Tom quailed. But presently the temptation rose up strong again and the boys agreed to try, with the understanding that they would take to their heels if the snoring stopped. So they went tiptoeing stealthily down, the one behind the other. When they had got to within five steps of the snorer, Tom stepped on a stick, and it broke with a sharp snap. The man moaned, writhed a little, and his face came into the moonlight. It was Muff Potter. The boys’ hearts had stood still, and their hopes too, when the man moved, but their fears passed away now. They tip-toed out, through the broken weather-boarding, and stopped at a little distance to exchange a parting word.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
Based on the provided metadata, I'll create a literary segment that captures the essence of this scene while avoiding direct reproduction of any copyrighted material:

---

Tom choked off and whispered:
"Look, Hucky, look! He's got his back to us!"

Huckleberry glanced over and his face brightened. "You're right! Was he that way before?"

"Yes—I was too scared to notice. This is wonderful news! Maybe the sign isn't for us after all."

Just then, the mournful howling ceased. Tom's head jerked up.

"Listen!" he whispered urgently. "What's that?"

Huckleberry tilted his head. "Sounds like... maybe hogs grunting?" He paused, concentrating. "No—someone's snoring!"

"That's what I think too," Tom agreed. "Where's it coming from?"

"Sounds like the far end of the tannery," Huckleberry replied. "My pap used to sleep there sometimes with the hogs when he..." He trailed off, then added, "Don't reckon he'll be back in town anytime soon though."

The boys exchanged glances, a familiar spark of adventure rekindling in their eyes despite their earlier fears.

"Hucky," Tom whispered, "do you dare go see if I lead?"

Huckleberry hesitated. "I don't much like it, Tom. What if—what if it's Injun Joe in there?"

A shiver ran through Tom at the name, but curiosity quickly overpowered his momentary dread.

"If he stops snoring, we'll run," Tom suggested. "Agreed?"

Huckleberry nodded reluctantly.

They crept forward on tiptoe, one behind the other, hearts pounding. When they were about five steps from the source of the snoring, Tom's foot found a dry twig that snapped with a sound that seemed to them as loud as a pistol shot.

The sleeping man groaned and shifted position. His face caught the moonlight, and the boys recognized Muff Potter. Their rigid bodies relaxed with relief that it wasn't the person they most feared.

Without a word, they slipped through a gap in the broken wall and only stopped to speak when they were safely away from the tannery.

---

events.title: Interpreting Omens for Muff Potter and Parting Ways
detailed_summary: Just as they are about to part, the long, mournful howl of the stray dog rises again on the night air.
The boys turn and see the strange dog standing very close to where Muff Potter is lying asleep.
Crucially, the dog is facing Potter, with its nose pointed upwards towards the sky, a classic posture for a death omen.
In unison, both Tom and Huckleberry exclaim that the dog's ominous presence is directed at Muff Potter.

Huckleberry then recounts a local story about a stray dog howling near Johnny Miller's house about two weeks prior, an event followed by a whippoorwill (another ill omen) landing and singing on the banisters the same evening, yet no one at the Miller house had died.

Tom acknowledges the story but counters by reminding Huckleberry that Gracie Miller subsequently had a serious accident, falling into the kitchen fire and getting terribly burned the following Saturday.
Huckleberry argues that Gracie Miller is not dead and, furthermore, is recovering from her injuries.

Tom dismisses this, insisting with certainty that Gracie is "a goner," and by extension, Muff Potter is also doomed. He attributes this knowledge to "the niggers," whom he claims are experts in understanding such omens.
After this exchange, the two boys separate, each lost in thought about the night's events and the superstitions discussed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That long, lugubrious howl rose on the night air again!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they separated, cogitating.

events.text_segment:
That long, lugubrious howl rose on the night air again! They turned and saw the strange dog standing within a few feet of where Potter was lying, and facing Potter, with his nose pointing heavenward.
“Oh, geeminy, it’s him!” exclaimed both boys, in a breath.
“Say, Tom—they say a stray dog come howling around Johnny Miller’s house, ’bout midnight, as much as two weeks ago; and a whippoorwill come in and lit on the banisters and sung, the very same evening; and there ain’t anybody dead there yet.”
“Well, I know that. And suppose there ain’t. Didn’t Gracie Miller fall in the kitchen fire and burn herself terrible the very next Saturday?”
“Yes, but she ain’t dead. And what’s more, she’s getting better, too.”
“All right, you wait and see. She’s a goner, just as dead sure as Muff Potter’s a goner. That’s what the niggers say, and they know all about these kind of things, Huck.”
Then they separated, cogitating.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
**text_segment**:

That long, lugubrious howl rose on the night air again! The boys turned and saw the strange dog standing within a few feet of where Potter was lying, and facing Potter, with his nose pointing heavenward.

"Oh, my! that's him," exclaimed both boys, in a breath.

"Oh, Huck, he's facing Potter, ain't he?"

"Lord, Tom, they say a stray dog that howls around like that at night is 'omen-ing' death! And they say he 'omens' it to anybody that's a-going to die! I wisht I knowed who he's a-'omen-ing' this time."

"Why, it's Potter, of course—it stands to reason. Becuz if he'd 'a' been facing one of us it would 'a' been t'other one of us, wouldn't it?"

"Yes, Tom, I reckon that's so. If it had 'a' been me, I'd 'a' said it was you."

"I bet it was. Say, Hucky, poor Potter don't know it. I reckon it's a good job he don't."

"Well, Tom, I reckon he's a goner. Don't you remember? Johnny Miller's dog done the same thing the night Johnny's father died."

"Yes, but look-a-here, Huck. Johnny Miller's dog didn't howl till midnight, and that was only about two weeks ago, and Johnny Miller's father died the very next day. And Johnny's dog howled again that night, and so did a whippoorwill, right on the house-top. And nobody's died there yet."

"Well, never mind, Huck, you wait and see. Potter'll be dead, and they'll blame it on the dog. That's what the niggers say, and they know all about these kind of things, Huck."

Then the boys separated, cogitating. When Tom crept in at his bedroom window the night was almost spent. He undressed with excessive caution, and fell asleep congratulating himself that nobody knew of his escapade. He was not aware that the gently-snoring Sid was awake, and had been so for an hour.

events.title: Tom's Stealthy Return and Silent Family Reproach
detailed_summary: Tom finally creeps in through his bedroom window as the night is nearly over.
He undresses with extreme care, moving stealthily, and falls asleep congratulating himself that his nocturnal adventure remains a secret.
He is completely unaware that his half-brother, Sid, who was gently snoring, had actually been awake for an hour and had observed his late return.
When Tom awakens, Sid is already dressed and gone. The light in the room and the general atmosphere feel unusually late.
He is immediately startled and wonders why he hadn't been called or nagged to get up, as was the daily custom. This deviation from routine fills him with a sense of foreboding.
Within five minutes, he is dressed and downstairs, feeling physically sore and mentally drowsy from his ordeal and lack of sleep.
He finds the family still at the breakfast table, though they have already finished their meal.
There is no verbal scolding, but he is met with averted eyes and a heavy, solemn silence that chills him to the core, making him feel like a culprit.

He sits down and attempts to appear cheerful and unconcerned, but his efforts are futile; he receives no smiles or responses, and soon lapses into silence himself, his spirits sinking to their lowest point.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When Tom crept in at his bedroom window the night was almost spent.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He sat down and tried to seem gay, but it was up-hill work; it roused no smile, no response, and he lapsed into silence and let his heart sink down to the depths.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
**text_segment**: 

When Tom crept in at his bedroom window the night was almost spent. He was careful to make no noise, and he stripped off his shoes before he entered. He slipped cautiously from the window to the floor, and then crawled to his bed and into it, all the while supposing that he was successfully eluding observation. But in this he was mistaken. Sid was awake, and had been so for an hour. He had been awake when Tom entered. There was a slight noise, and Sid made as if he was just turning over in his sleep. Tom lay perfectly still, listening. Presently the stealthy breathing of Sid showed that he was asleep. Tom rose up in bed, cautiously, and looked at his brother. Sid lay motionless. Tom slipped out of bed, and dressed himself with laborious care not to make a sound. Then he waited a good while, as it seemed to him, for Sid to betray some sign of wakefulness; but Sid snored on peacefully. Tom crept out of the room, closing the door carefully behind him. He was a free man! He tiptoed down the stairs and out of the house.

When Tom awoke in the morning, Sid was dressed and gone. There was a late look in the light, a late sense in the atmosphere. He was startled. Why had he not been called—persecuted till he was up, as usual? The thought filled him with bodings. Within five minutes he was dressed and down-stairs, feeling sore and drowsy. The family were still at table, but they had finished breakfast. There was no voice of rebuke; but there were averted eyes; there was a silence and an air of solemnity that struck a chill to the culprit's heart. He sat down and tried to seem gay, but it was up-hill work; it roused no smile, no response, and he lapsed into silence and let his heart sink down to the depths.

After breakfast his aunt took him aside, and Tom almost brightened in the hope that he was going to be flogged; but it was not so. His aunt wept over him and asked him how he could go and break her old heart so; and finally told him to go on, and ruin himself and bring her gray hairs with sorrow to the grave, for it was no use for her to try any more. This was worse than a thousand whippings, and Tom's heart was sorer now than his body. He cried, he promised to reform over and over again, and then received his dismissal, feeling that he had won but an imperfect forgiveness and established but a feeble confidence.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Heartfelt Reprimand and Tom's Deep Remorse
detailed_summary: After the silent breakfast, Aunt Polly takes Tom aside for a private conversation.
Tom, anticipating punishment, almost feels a sense of relief, hoping he is about to receive a flogging, which he considers a more bearable consequence.
However, his aunt does not resort to physical punishment. Instead, she weeps over him, expressing her profound sorrow and asking how he could repeatedly break her old heart with his behavior.

She tells him, with an air of resignation, to continue on his path to self-ruin and to bring her "gray hairs with sorrow to the grave," as she feels it is useless for her to try and guide him any longer.
This emotional reprimand, filled with her pain and disappointment, affects Tom far more deeply than a thousand whippings could have; his heart feels sorer than his body.
Overwhelmed with guilt and remorse, Tom cries, earnestly pleads for his aunt's forgiveness, and makes repeated promises to reform his ways.
He is eventually dismissed by his aunt, leaving with the distinct feeling that he has only managed to obtain an imperfect forgiveness and has established only a very fragile level of trust.

His misery is so profound that he doesn't even feel any resentment or desire for revenge against Sid for likely betraying him; consequently, Sid's cautious retreat through the back gate upon Tom's approach is unnecessary.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After breakfast his aunt took him aside, and Tom almost brightened in the hope that he was going to be flogged; but it was not so.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He left the presence too miserable to even feel revengeful toward Sid; and so the latter’s prompt retreat through the back gate was unnecessary.

events.title: Misery at School and a Crushing Discovery
detailed_summary: Tom walks to school in a state of gloom and sadness, his earlier escapades weighing heavily on him.
Along with Joe Harper, he receives a flogging from the schoolmaster for having played hooky the previous day.
Tom endures the physical punishment with a detached air, as if his mind is preoccupied with far more significant sorrows, rendering the flogging a mere trifle in comparison.
He then takes his seat, rests his elbows on his desk and his chin in his hands, and stares blankly at the wall with the stony expression of someone who has reached the utmost limit of suffering.
His elbow is uncomfortably pressing against a hard object on his desk.
After a considerable time, he slowly and sadly shifts his position and, with a sigh, picks up the object. It is wrapped in a piece of paper.
He unrolls the paper, revealing its contents. A long, drawn-out, colossal sigh escapes him, and his heart feels as though it breaks.
The object is his cherished brass andiron knob, a treasure he had previously given to Becky Thatcher. Its return signifies a deeper emotional blow.
This final disappointment, this seemingly small thing on top of all his other woes, proves to be the ultimate burden, the "final feather" that metaphorically breaks his spirit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He moped to school gloomy and sad, and took his flogging, along with Joe Harper, for playing hookey the day before, with the air of one whose heart was busy with heavier woes and wholly dead to trifles.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This final feather broke the camel’s back.

events.text_segment:
He moped to school gloomy and sad, and took his flogging, along with Joe Harper, for playing hookey the day before, with the air of one whose heart was busy with heavier woes and wholly dead to trifles. Then he betook himself to his seat, rested his elbows on his desk and his jaws in his hands, and stared at the wall with the stony stare of suffering that has reached the limit and can no further go. His elbow was pressing against some hard substance. After a long time he slowly and sadly changed his position, and took up this object with a sigh. It was in a paper. He unrolled it. A long, lingering, colossal sigh followed, and his heart broke. It was his brass andiron knob!
This final feather broke the camel’s back.

events.title: Swift Spread of Murder News and Potter's Implication
detailed_summary: News of a murder spreads with astonishing speed throughout the village around noon.
The schoolmaster, acknowledging the gravity of the situation, declares a holiday for the afternoon.
A blood-stained knife, identified by someone as belonging to Muff Potter, was discovered near the deceased.
Rumors circulated that Potter had been seen washing himself near a stream in the early morning hours and had suspiciously fled when approached, an unusual act for him.
It was also said that the town had thoroughly searched for Potter, whom the public had already judged as the murderer, but he remained unfound.
Mounted men were dispatched on all roads, and the Sheriff expressed confidence that Potter would be apprehended by nightfall.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Close upon the hour of noon the whole village was suddenly electrified with the ghastly news.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Horsemen had departed down all the roads in every direction, and the Sheriff “was confident” that he would be captured before night.

events.text_segment:
Close upon the hour of noon the whole village was suddenly electrified with the ghastly news. No need of the as yet un-dreamed-of telegraph; the tale flew from man to man, from group to group, from house to house, with little less than telegraphic speed. Of course the schoolmaster gave holiday for that afternoon; the town would have thought strangely of him if he had not.
A gory knife had been found close to the murdered man, and it had been recognized by somebody as belonging to Muff Potter—so the story ran. And it was said that a belated citizen had come upon Potter washing himself in the “branch” about one or two o’clock in the morning, and that Potter had at once sneaked off—suspicious circumstances, especially the washing which was not a habit with Potter. It was also said that the town had been ransacked for this “murderer” (the public are not slow in the matter of sifting evidence and arriving at a verdict), but that he could not be found. Horsemen had departed down all the roads in every direction, and the Sheriff “was confident” that he would be captured before night.

No need of the as yet undreamed-of telegraph; the tale flew from man to man, from group to group, from house to house, with little less than telegraphic speed. Of course the schoolmaster gave holiday for that afternoon; the town would have thought strangely of him if he had not.

A gory knife had been found close to the murdered man, and it had been recognized by somebody as belonging to Muff Potter—so the story ran. And it was said that a belated citizen had come upon Potter washing himself in the "branch" about one or two o'clock in the morning, and that Potter had at once sneaked off—suspicious circumstances, especially the washing which was not a habit with Potter. events.title: Somber Gathering at the Graveyard and Boys' Anxious Exchange
detailed_summary: The entire populace of the town began to make its way to the graveyard.
Tom's distress over his own matters faded, and he found himself compelled by a strange fascination to join the procession, despite wishing he could be anywhere else.
Upon arriving at the ominous location, Tom squeezed through the crowd to witness the grim scene, which felt like an eternity since his last visit.
He was startled by a pinch on his arm and turned to see Huckleberry Finn; they quickly averted their gazes, worried if anyone had observed their interaction.
However, everyone present was engrossed in conversation and the macabre spectacle before them.
Comments from the crowd lamented the victim's fate, suggested it was a warning to grave robbers, and predicted Muff Potter would be hanged.
The minister declared the event an act of divine judgment.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All the town was drifting toward the graveyard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: This was the drift of remark; and the minister said, “It was a judgment; His hand is here.”

events.text_segment:
All the town was drifting toward the graveyard. Tom’s heartbreak vanished and he joined the procession, not because he would not a thousand times rather go anywhere else, but because an awful, unaccountable fascination drew him on. Arrived at the dreadful place, he wormed his small body through the crowd and saw the dismal spectacle. It seemed to him an age since he was there before. Somebody pinched his arm. He turned, and his eyes met Huckleberry’s. Then both looked elsewhere at once, and wondered if anybody had noticed anything in their mutual glance. But everybody was talking, and intent upon the grisly spectacle before them.
“Poor fellow!” “Poor young fellow!” “This ought to be a lesson to grave robbers!” “Muff Potter’ll hang for this if they catch him!” This was the drift of remark; and the minister said, “It was a judgment; His hand is here.”

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
**text_segment**: All the town was drifting toward the graveyard. Tom's heartache vanished, for the moment, and he joined the procession, with a dim feeling that he would rather be anywhere else, but an awful, mysterious charm fascinated him on. Arrived at the dread place, he wormed his way through the crowd and saw the dismal spectacle. It seemed to him an age since he was there before. Somebody pinched his arm. He turned, and his eyes met Huckleberry's. Then both looked elsewhere at once, and wondered if anybody had noticed anything in their mutual glance. But everybody was talking, and intent upon the grisly spectacle before them.

"Poor fellow!" "Poor young fellow!" "This ought to be a lesson to grave robbers!" "Muff Potter'll hang for this if they catch him!" This was the drift of remark; and the minister said, "It was a judgment; His hand is here."

Now Tom shivered from head to heel; for his eye fell upon the stolid face of Injun Joe. At this moment the crowd began to sway and struggle, and voices shouted, "It's him! it's him! he's coming himself!"

"Who? Who?" from twenty voices.

"Muff Potter!"

"Hallo, he's stopped!—Look out, he's turning! Don't let him get away!"

People in the branches of the trees over Tom's head said he wasn't trying to get away—he only looked doubtful and perplexed.

"Infernal impudence!" said a bystander; "wanted to come and take a quiet look at his work, I reckon—didn't expect any company."

The crowd fell apart, now, and the Sheriff came through, ostentatiously leading Potter by the arm. The poor fellow's face was haggard, and his eyes showed the fear that was upon him. When he stood before the murdered man, he shook as with a palsy, and he put his face in his hands and burst into tears.

events.title: Potter's Apprehension and Public Confrontation
detailed_summary: Tom experienced a sudden chill as his gaze met the impassive face of Injun Joe.
At that moment, the crowd stirred, and voices announced the arrival of Muff Potter himself.
People in trees above Tom observed that Potter did not seem to be trying to flee but appeared uncertain and bewildered.
A bystander remarked on Potter's audacity, speculating he had come to observe his supposed crime scene, not anticipating an audience.
The crowd parted to allow the Sheriff to pass, conspicuously leading Potter by the arm.
Potter looked worn and his eyes betrayed his deep fear; upon seeing the murdered man, he trembled violently, covered his face, and began to weep.
He sobbed, insisting on his innocence and honor.
A voice from the crowd shouted, questioning who had accused him.
This query seemed to deeply affect Potter, who looked around with a sorrowful, defeated expression before his eyes landed on Injun Joe, at which point he started to speak about a promise.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now Tom shivered from head to heel; for his eye fell upon the stolid face of Injun Joe.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Oh, Injun Joe, you promised me you’d never—”

events.text_segment:
Now Tom shivered from head to heel; for his eye fell upon the stolid face of Injun Joe. At this moment the crowd began to sway and struggle, and voices shouted, “It’s him! it’s him! he’s coming himself!”
“Who? Who?” from twenty voices.
“Muff Potter!”
“Hallo, he’s stopped!—Look out, he’s turning! Don’t let him get away!”
People in the branches of the trees over Tom’s head said he wasn’t trying to get away—he only looked doubtful and perplexed.
“Infernal impudence!” said a bystander; “wanted to come and take a quiet look at his work, I reckon—didn’t expect any company.”
The crowd fell apart, now, and the Sheriff came through, ostentatiously leading Potter by the arm. The poor fellow’s face was haggard, and his eyes showed the fear that was upon him. When he stood before the murdered man, he shook as with a palsy, and he put his face in his hands and burst into tears.
“I didn’t do it, friends,” he sobbed; “’pon my word and honor I never done it.”
“Who’s accused you?” shouted a voice.
This shot seemed to carry home. Potter lifted his face and looked around him with a pathetic hopelessness in his eyes. He saw Injun Joe, and exclaimed:
“Oh, Injun Joe, you promised me you’d never—”

events.title: Injun Joe's Deception and the Boys' Terrified Silence
detailed_summary: The Sheriff presented Potter with the knife.

Potter nearly collapsed but was supported and lowered to the ground, after which he expressed a premonition about returning for something, then, with a defeated gesture, urged Joe to tell the others, conceding futility.
Huckleberry and Tom, speechless and staring, listened as Injun Joe, whom they considered a heartless liar, calmly recounted his version of events.
The boys anticipated divine wrath to strike Joe down at any moment and were bewildered by the delay.

When Joe concluded his statement unharmed, their fleeting desire to break their vow and save the wrongly accused Potter dissipated, as they concluded Joe had made a pact with Satan, rendering interference with such a powerful entity perilous.
Someone questioned Potter why he hadn't left and why he had come to the scene.
Potter lamented that he couldn't resist returning, feeling inexplicably drawn to that specific place, and resumed sobbing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Is that your knife?” and it was thrust before him by the Sheriff.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And he fell to sobbing again.

events.text_segment:
“Is that your knife?” and it was thrust before him by the Sheriff.
Potter would have fallen if they had not caught him and eased him to the ground. Then he said:
“Something told me ’t if I didn’t come back and get—” He shuddered; then waved his nerveless hand with a vanquished gesture and said, “Tell ’em, Joe, tell ’em—it ain’t any use any more.”
Then Huckleberry and Tom stood dumb and staring, and heard the stony-hearted liar reel off his serene statement, they expecting every moment that the clear sky would deliver God’s lightnings upon his head, and wondering to see how long the stroke was delayed. And when he had finished and still stood alive and whole, their wavering impulse to break their oath and save the poor betrayed prisoner’s life faded and vanished away, for plainly this miscreant had sold himself to Satan and it would be fatal to meddle with the property of such a power as that.
“Why didn’t you leave? What did you want to come here for?” somebody said.
“I couldn’t help it—I couldn’t help it,” Potter moaned. “I wanted to run away, but I couldn’t seem to come anywhere but here.” And he fell to sobbing again.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
**text_segment**:

"Is that your knife?" and it was thrust before him by the Sheriff.

Potter took it with a limp hand and dropped it with a shudder. Then he fell to crying, and said:

"Something told me 't if I didn't come back and get—" He shook his head and bent his form till his forehead rested upon his knees, sobbing convulsively: "Tell 'em, Joe, tell 'em—it ain't any use any more."

Then Huckleberry and Tom stood dumb and staring, and heard the stony-hearted liar reel off his serene statement, they expecting every moment that the clear sky would deliver God's lightnings upon his head, and wondering to see how long the stroke was delayed. And when he had finished and still stood alive and whole, their wavering impulse to break their oath and save the poor betrayed prisoner's life faded and vanished away, for plainly this miscreant had sold himself to Satan and it would be fatal to meddle with the property of such a power as that.

"Why didn't you leave? What did you want to come here for?" somebody said.

"I couldn't help it—I couldn't help it," Potter moaned. "I wanted to run away, but I couldn't seem to come anywhere but here." And he fell to sobbing again.

Injun Joe repeated his statement, just as calmly, a few minutes afterward on the inquest, under oath; and the boys, seeing that the lightnings were still withheld, were confirmed in their belief that Joe had sold himself to the devil. He was now become, to them, the most balefully interesting object they had ever looked upon, and they could not take their fascinated eyes from his face.

events.title: The Inquest and Misinterpreted Omens
detailed_summary: Injun Joe calmly repeated his false account under oath during the inquest a short time later, reinforcing the boys' conviction that he had made a deal with the devil.
To Tom and Huckleberry, Joe became an object of dreadful fascination, and they couldn't tear their eyes away from him.
They silently resolved to watch him during the nights, when possible, hoping to catch a glimpse of his supposed diabolical associate.
As Injun Joe assisted in moving the victim's body to a wagon, a whisper spread through the horrified crowd that the wound had bled slightly.
The boys hoped this occurrence would direct suspicion appropriately, but they were disappointed when several villagers remarked that it happened when Muff Potter was nearby.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Injun Joe repeated his statement, just as calmly, a few minutes afterward on the inquest, under oath; and the boys, seeing that the lightnings were still withheld, were confirmed in their belief that Joe had sold himself to the devil.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “It was within three feet of Muff Potter when it done it.”

events.text_segment:
Injun Joe repeated his statement, just as calmly, a few minutes afterward on the inquest, under oath; and the boys, seeing that the lightnings were still withheld, were confirmed in their belief that Joe had sold himself to the devil. He was now become, to them, the most balefully interesting object they had ever looked upon, and they could not take their fascinated eyes from his face.
They inwardly resolved to watch him nights, when opportunity should offer, in the hope of getting a glimpse of his dread master.
Injun Joe helped to raise the body of the murdered man and put it in a wagon for removal; and it was whispered through the shuddering crowd that the wound bled a little! The boys thought that this happy circumstance would turn suspicion in the right direction; but they were disappointed, for more than one villager remarked:
“It was within three feet of Muff Potter when it done it.”

They inwardly resolved to watch him nights, when opportunity should offer, in the hope of getting a glimpse of his dread master.

Tom and Huck were willing to take anybody's money now, but they were not willing to be found in anybody's company. Conscience was sore, but remorse was sorer. The boys agreed that they could never expose Potter, but they must shield him if they could.

When the inquest was over, they felt just as insecure as they were before. Tom's conscience could not bring itself to exact full justice from the real murderer.

"Why didn't you ever tell, Tom?"

"I was afeard to tell, and I ain't afeard any more. But that ain't it. They'd hang him sure, and I couldn't stand it."

Injun Joe helped to raise the body of the murdered man and put it in a wagon for removal; and it was whispered through the shuddering crowd that the wound bled a little! The boys thought that this happy circumstance would turn suspicion in the right direction; but they were disappointed, for more than one villager remarked:

"It was within three feet of Muff Potter when it done it."

events.title: Tom's Troubled Sleep and Sid's Scrutiny
detailed_summary: Tom's heavy secret and guilty conscience disrupted his sleep for about a week following these events, and one morning at breakfast, Sid mentioned it.
Sid informed Aunt Polly that Tom thrashed around and talked extensively in his sleep, keeping Sid awake.
Tom turned pale and looked down, visibly shaken.
Aunt Polly gravely remarked that it was a bad sign and asked Tom what was troubling him.
Tom denied knowing of anything, but his hand trembled so much he spilled his coffee.
Sid elaborated that Tom had repeatedly muttered about blood and threatened to reveal something, questioning what Tom would tell.
Tom felt overwhelmed, but Aunt Polly, unaware of the true cause, inadvertently eased his distress by attributing his behavior to the recent horrifying murder, saying she also dreamt about it.
Mary mentioned she had experienced similar effects, and Sid appeared content with the explanation.
Tom left their presence as swiftly as he could and, for the following week, feigned a toothache, bandaging his jaw each night.
He remained unaware that Sid would often watch him, remove the bandage to listen to his mutterings for extended periods, and then replace it, keeping any findings to himself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Tom’s fearful secret and gnawing conscience disturbed his sleep for as much as a week after this; and at breakfast one morning Sid said:
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: If Sid really managed to make anything out of Tom’s disjointed mutterings, he kept it to himself.

events.text_segment:
Tom’s fearful secret and gnawing conscience disturbed his sleep for as much as a week after this; and at breakfast one morning Sid said:
“Tom, you pitch around and talk in your sleep so much that you keep me awake half the time.”
Tom blanched and dropped his eyes.
“It’s a bad sign,” said Aunt Polly, gravely. “What you got on your mind, Tom?”
“Nothing. Nothing ’t I know of.” But the boy’s hand shook so that he spilled his coffee.
“And you do talk such stuff,” Sid said. “Last night you said, ‘It’s blood, it’s blood, that’s what it is!’ You said that over and over. And you said, ‘Don’t torment me so—I’ll tell!’ Tell what? What is it you’ll tell?”
Everything was swimming before Tom. There is no telling what might have happened, now, but luckily the concern passed out of Aunt Polly’s face and she came to Tom’s relief without knowing it. She said:
“Sho! It’s that dreadful murder. I dream about it most every night myself. Sometimes I dream it’s me that done it.”
Mary said she had been affected much the same way. Sid seemed satisfied. Tom got out of the presence as quick as he plausibly could, and after that he complained of toothache for a week, and tied up his jaws every night. He never knew that Sid lay nightly watching, and frequently slipped the bandage free and then leaned on his elbow listening a good while at a time, and afterward slipped the bandage back to its place again. Tom’s distress of mind wore off gradually and the toothache grew irksome and was discarded. If Sid really managed to make anything out of Tom’s disjointed mutterings, he kept it to himself.

events.title: Tom's Aversion to Mock Inquests and Sid's Continued Observation
detailed_summary: Tom felt that his schoolmates would never cease conducting mock inquests on deceased cats, which served as a constant painful reminder of his predicament.
Sid observed that Tom, who typically led new activities, never served as coroner in these mock trials.
Sid also noted, with surprise, that Tom never acted as a witness in these games.
Furthermore, Sid did not fail to notice Tom's pronounced dislike for these inquests and his efforts to avoid them whenever possible.
Sid was intrigued by this change but refrained from commenting.
Eventually, however, the fad of holding mock inquests subsided, providing Tom relief from that particular source of mental anguish.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It seemed to Tom that his schoolmates never would get done holding inquests on dead cats, and thus keeping his trouble present to his mind.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, even inquests went out of vogue at last, and ceased to torture Tom’s conscience.

events.text_segment: It seemed to Tom that his schoolmates never would get done holding inquests on dead cats, and thus keeping his trouble present to his mind. Sid noticed that Tom never was coroner at one of these inquiries, though it had been his habit to take the lead in all new enterprises; he noticed, too, that Tom never acted as a witness—and that was strange; and Sid did not overlook the fact that Tom even showed a marked aversion to these inquests, and always avoided them when he could. Sid marvelled, but said nothing. However, even inquests went out of vogue at last, and ceased to torture Tom’s conscience.
